issues.text: Whether the High Court erred in acquitting Jagir Singh, Baljit Singh and Karam Singh by giving them the benefit of doubt and setting aside their convictions under Sections 302, 302/34 and 307/34 IPC

anchor.surface_text: Learned Sessions Judge found that the prosecution case against Joginder Singh, Baljit Singh and Karam Singh accused had been proved beyond any shadow of doubt. He accepted the ocular evidence produced in the case. Reliance was, however, not placed upon the dying declarations of Lakha Singh and Joginder Singh. The remaining six accused were given the benefit of doubt and were acquitted. The High Court on appeal and reference acquitted Jagir Singh, Baljit Singh and Karam Singh also by giving them the benefit of doubt for reasons which would be dealt with hereafter.

issues.text: Whether the ocular evidence of eyewitnesses is reliable and proves the complicity of the accused beyond reasonable doubt despite their relationship to the deceased
Whether there was unexplained delay in lodging the FIR so as to affect the credibility of the prosecution case

anchor.surface_text: lodged there report P.A. at 11.15 p.m.... Another fact of which note should be taken is that the first information report in this case was lodged at 11.15 p.m., within a few hours of the occurrence. Although Mr. Nuruddin has urged that there was delay in lodging the first information report, we find it difficult to accept this submission.

issues.text: Whether the place of occurrence was the courtyard of Labh Singh's house or near the village gurudwara as suggested by defence

anchor.surface_text: The defence suggestion which was put in the cross examination of the prosecution witnesses was that a number of persons had collected near the village gurudwara when a hand-grenade exploded there and the three deceased persons and the prosecution witnesses received injuries. This suggestion, in the circumstances of the case, was, in our opinion, wholly unfounded.

issues.text: Whether identification of assailants was possible given the height of the compound wall, lighting conditions and time of occurrence
Whether the injury on the nose of Harbans Singh PW was caused by kirpan or hand-grenade splinter, affecting credibility of witnesses
Whether Labh Singh deceased was present at the place of occurrence or away in Pathankot at the time
Whether the sentence of death under Section 302 IPC should be confirmed or reduced considering the lapse of time since acquittal

anchor.surface_text: for the offence under section 302 Indian Penal Code, we find that a period of more than two years has elapsed since the acquittal of the accused-respondents by the High Court. It would, in the circumstances, be appropriate if the extreme penalty for the offence under section 302 Indian Penal Code is not exacted from the accused-respondents.

holdings.text: The High Court erred in acquitting Jagir Singh, Baljit Singh and Karam Singh; the prosecution case is proved beyond reasonable doubt and convictions under Sections 302, 302/34 and 307/34 IPC are restored.
holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court relied on conjectures and surmises; prosecution ocular evidence trustworthy, corroborated by FIR and medical evidence; Sessions Judge correct.

holdings.text: Ocular evidence of eyewitnesses is reliable and proves complicity of accused beyond reasonable doubt despite relationship to deceased.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Relatives scrutinized closely but evidence stands test; unlikely to spare real culprits; injured witnesses confirm presence.

holdings.text: No unexplained delay in lodging FIR; prompt report within few hours corroborates ocular evidence.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly accept the appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court and convict the accused-respondents for the offences for which they were convicted by the trial court. It would, in the circumstances, be appropriate if the extreme penalty for the offence under section 302 Indian Penal Code is not
